context: [DOC] [TLE] First man in space - Apr 12, 1961 - HISTORY.comFirst man in space - Apr 12, 1961 - HISTORY.com [PAR] First man in space [PAR] Publisher [PAR] A+E Networks [PAR] On April 12, 1961, aboard the spacecraft Vostok 1, Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Alekseyevich Gagarin becomes the first human being to travel into space. During the flight, the 27-year-old test pilot and industrial technician also became the first man to orbit the planet, a feat accomplished by his space capsule in 89 minutes. Vostok 1 orbited Earth at a maximum altitude of 187 miles and was guided entirely by an automatic control system. The only statement attributed to Gagarin during his one hour and 48 minutes in space was, “Flight is proceeding normally; I am well.” [PAR] After his historic feat was announced, the attractive and unassuming Gagarin became an instant worldwide celebrity. He was awarded the Order of Lenin and given the title of Hero of the Soviet Union. Monuments were raised to him across the Soviet Union and streets renamed in his honor. [PAR] The triumph of the Soviet space program in putting the first man into space was a great blow to the United States, which had scheduled its first space flight for May 1961. Moreover, Gagarin had orbited Earth, a feat that eluded the U.S. space program until February 1962, when astronaut John Glenn made three orbits in Friendship 7. By that time, the Soviet Union had already made another leap ahead in the “space race” with the August 1961 flight of cosmonaut Gherman Titov in Vostok 2. Titov made 17 orbits and spent more than 25 hours in space. [PAR] To Soviet propagandists, the Soviet conquest of space was evidence of the supremacy of communism over capitalism. However, to those who worked on the Vostok program and earlier on Sputnik (which launched the first satellite into space in 1957), the successes were attributable chiefly to the brilliance of one man: Sergei Pavlovich Korolev. Because of his controversial past, Chief Designer Korolev was unknown in the West and to all but insiders in the USSR until his death in 1966. [PAR] Born in the Ukraine in 1906, Korolev was part of a scientific team that launched the first Soviet liquid-fueled rocket in 1933. In 1938, his military sponsor fell prey to Soviet leader Joseph Stalin’s purges, and Korolev and his colleagues were also put on trial. Convicted of treason and sabotage, Korolev was sentenced to 10 years in a labor camp. The Soviet authorities came to fear German rocket advances, however, and after only a year Korolev was put in charge of a prison design bureau and ordered to continue his rocketry work. [PAR] In 1945, Korolev was sent to Germany to learn about the V-2 rocket, which had been used to devastating effect by the Nazis against the British. The Americans had captured the rocket’s designer, Wernher von Braun, who later became head of the U.S. space program, but the Soviets acquired a fair amount of V-2 resources, including rockets, launch facilities, blueprints, and a few German V-2 technicians. By employing this technology and his own considerable engineering talents, by 1954 Korolev had built a rocket that could carry a five-ton nuclear warhead and in 1957 launched the first intercontinental ballistic missile. [PAR] That year, Korolev’s plan to launch a satellite into space was approved, and on October 4, 1957, Sputnik 1 was fired into Earth’s orbit. It was the first Soviet victory of the space race, and Korolev, still technically a prisoner, was officially rehabilitated. The Soviet space program under Korolev would go on to numerous space firsts in the late 1950s and early ’60s: first animal in orbit, first large scientific satellite, first man, first woman, first three men, first space walk, first spacecraft to impact the moon, first to orbit the moon, first to impact Venus, and first craft to soft-land on the moon. Throughout this time, Korolev remained anonymous, known only as the “Chief Designer.” His dream of sending cosmonauts to the moon eventually ended in failure, primarily because the Soviet lunar program received just one-tenth the funding allocated to America’s successful Apollo lunar landing
topic: The acquisition and adaptation of German V-2 rocket technology by the Soviet Union and its influence on Soviet missile and space capabilities.
question: Which factor most critically enabled the Soviet Union to transition from adapting German V-2 rocket technology to independently achieving major space milestones such as launching Sputnik and Vostok 1?

choices.A: Continued reliance on German V-2 technicians and direct replication of V-2 designs
choices.B: The integration of V-2-derived hardware with domestic innovations led by Sergei Korolev
choices.C: Exclusive focus on developing nuclear warheads without further V-2 influence
choices.D: Prioritizing Soviet propaganda over substantive technological development

explanation: While the Soviets acquired V-2 rockets, facilities, and some German technicians, it was the combination of this foundation with significant domestic engineering innovations—particularly under Korolev’s leadership—that enabled the creation of new rocket families capable of space launch, moving beyond mere replication of V-2 technology.

context: [DOC] [TLE] PLEASE SIR! | A TELEVISION HEAVEN REVIEWPLEASE SIR! | A TELEVISION HEAVEN REVIEW [PAR]   [PAR] PLEASE SIR! / THE FENN STREET GANG (1968) [PAR] Possibly inspired by the 1967 Sidney Potier movie, 'To Sir, With Love' -'Please Sir!' starred former Emergency Ward 10 actor John Alderton as newly qualified teacher Bernard Hedges (specialising in History and English), as he tried to tame the most unruly class at Fenn Street School; 5C. [PAR] On his first day at school Bernard crossed swords with caretaker Norman Potter (Deryck Guyler), a former Desert Rat with delusions of grandeur, although with some credibility as he was the right hand man of incompetent headmaster, Maurice Cromwell (Noel Howlett), who in turn was the subject of infatuation by formidable deputy head Doris Ewell (Joan Sanderson). This trio virtually ran the school much to the resignation of the rest of the disillusioned staff and the last thing they wanted to disturb the balance was a young schoolmaster fresh out of teachers training college and full of bright ideals about modern teaching. [PAR] In order to curb Bernard's naïve enthusiasm it was conspired between the trio to give him a class of 'no-hopers', namely 5C. In their last year at school the pupils of this class were an uneducable bunch of delinquents who were simply biding their time until the final bell sounded on the last day of term. This of course did not involve participating in any school activities such as lessons. However, through a series of (comical) events Bernard managed to win over not only the staff but also the class of pupils (who nicknamed him 'Privet' Hedges) that contained 'hard case' Patrick Duffy (Peter Cleall), the tough talking but wimpish Frankie (Hank) Abbott (David Barry), slow witted Dennis Dunstable (Peter Denyer), flirtatious Sharon (Penny Spencer in the first two season's, Carol Hawkins thereafter), and Maureen (Liz Gebhart), who had a crush on her teacher. Support on the teacher front came from Richard Davies who gave a first class performance as the down to earth no-nonsense Welsh science teacher, Mr Price, and the aging Eric Chitty as Mr Smith, a teacher that was clearly beyond retirement age at the series outset. In fact most of the actors who played the students were already in their twenties when Please Sir! began in 1968 and two years later (at the end of the longest last year in school history) the pupils were clearly showing their age. [PAR] The series made stars of several actors although oddly none of the students found lasting television fame. LWT Head of Light Entertainment, Frank Muir, cast Alderton as Bernard Hedges after he had spotted him as a teacher in the opening episode of Never A Cross Word. After leaving Fenn Street School the actor went on to several successful series such as Upstairs, Downstairs, it's spin-off series Thomas and Sarah, the LWT sitcom No-Honestly and a series of Wodehouse plays (Wodehouse Playhouse) for BBC (all of which Alderton co-starred alongside his wife, Pauline Collins), and the BBC sitcom My Wife Next Door with Hannah Gordon. Joan Sanderson won television immortality as Mrs Richards, the hotel guest with hearing problems in Fawlty Towers and after Please Sir! had finished she teamed up again with Deryck Guyler (who was originally cast as Fenn Street's headmaster) on a BBC radio show (also penned by the same writers), You're Only Young Once. [PAR] A 1971 feature movie was released in which Bernard meets and begins to date Penny Wheeler (Jill Kerman), and this was carried on in subsequent TV series of Please Sir! and its predecessor, The Fenn Street Gang (which in turn spawned Bowler), which briefly followed the fortunes of the pupils after they left school. [PAR] The series was the creation of former school chums and a new-to-television comedy writing team of John Esmonde and Bob Larbey, who went on to write Get Some In!; Ever Decreasing Circles; As Time Goes By and the enormously successful The Good Life. Actor David Barry has fond memories of working on
topic: The influence of "To Sir, With Love" on the conceptualization and narrative structure of "Please Sir!".
question: In what primary way did "Please Sir!" adapt the premise of "To Sir, With Love" to create a distinct narrative structure, and how did this adaptation affect the portrayal of institutional authority within the school setting?

choices.A: By maintaining a dramatic tone but shifting focus to student backstories, thus marginalizing the role of teachers.
choices.B: By adopting a comedic approach and emphasizing staffroom politics, thereby critiquing institutional inertia rather than solely focusing on student redemption.
choices.C: By replicating the film’s structure exactly, including the teacher’s personal transformation as the central theme.
choices.D: By excluding any focus on the difficulties of teaching, instead presenting the school as entirely harmonious.

explanation: The sitcom "Please Sir!" adapted the central premise of a new teacher facing an unruly class from "To Sir, With Love" but shifted to a comedic approach and highlighted the resistance of school staff to change, using staffroom dynamics to critique institutional inertia. This differs from the film’s more dramatic, student-centered redemption arc.

context: [DOC] [TLE] What are the Halogens in the Periodic Table? - QuoraWhat are the Halogens in the Periodic Table? - Quora [PAR] Quora [PAR] Daniel James Berger , PhD in organic chemistry [PAR] The elements in Group 17 of the periodic table  ( The Old fashioned name for Group 17 is Group VII ) are known collectively as The Halogens. [PAR] They are the elements Fluorine, ( atomic number 9 ),  Chlorine, ( atomic number 17 ), Bromine ( atomic number 35 ), Iodine ( atomic number 53 ), Astatine  ( atomic number 85 ), and a newly discovered element not yet given a name, that has an atomic number of 117, ( Discovered in 2010). [PAR] However both Astatine and Element No. 117 are too radioactive to be made in quantities that can be weighed. They are man made elements that have very short half lives;  so decay into other elements before one has the chance to make any of their compounds. So in most laboratories Halogen chemistry is essentially about the study of Fluorine, Chlorine, Bromine & Iodine. [PAR] The word Halogen was coined in 1842 by the Swedish Chemist Berzelius ( 1779 - 1848 ). It is a made up Swedish word which literally means "Salt producer" in Swedish. A name in keeping with the reactive nature of these elements. Lots of Halogen salts are known. Eg. Sodium chloride. Potassium fluoride. Sodium Bromide. [PAR]  These elements are all members of the same group, because all of their atoms have the same number of electrons in their outermost shell or orbit. Group 17 elements all have 7 electrons in their outermost orbit. [PAR] ​ [PAR] ​The Periodic Table highlighting Group 17. [PAR] Fluorine [PAR] As mentioned previously fluorine has an atomic number of 9. This means that an atom of fluorine will have in addition to 9 protons in the nucleus of its atom, it will have a total of 9 electrons orbiting its nucleus. An individual  proton always has a charge of +1 and an individual electron always has a charge of -1. [PAR] We have 9 protons in an atom of fluorine each having a charge of +1, plus 9 electrons in that same atom orbiting the nucleus of that atom. [PAR] ( +1 X 9 ) + (-1 X 9 ) = 0. [PAR]  So the atom is electrically neutral. [PAR] This is true for all neutral atoms of fluorine. [PAR] The 9 electrons are arranged in 2 shells or orbit.  2 of the 9 electrons orbit in the 1st shell or orbit. The remaining 7 electrons orbit in a larger shell. [PAR] The 7 electrons in the outermost orbit of all Halogens are the electrons that participate in chemical reactions. During chemical reactions the number of electrons in the outermost orbit can go up or down. Up to a max of 8, and down to 0 ( in theory ). Compare with  Na+1 or with Li+1 [PAR] ​ [PAR] Written Feb 7, 2016 [PAR] The halogens are the family of chemical elements that includes fluorine (atomic symbol F), chlorine (Cl), bromine (Br), iodine (I), and astatine (At). The halogens make up Group VIIA of the Periodic Table of the elements. Elemental halogens are diatomic molecules. However, due to their high reactivity, the halogens are never found in nature in native form. The family name means "salt-forming," from the Greek for salt, "hals", and for generating "genes". The salinity of the oceans on Earth is due in large part to such halogen salts (halides) as sodium chloride (NaCl) and potassium iodide (KI). [PAR] Halogens display physical and chemical properties typical of nonmetals. They have relatively low melting and boiling points that increase steadily down the group. Near room temperature, the halogens span all of the physical states: Fluorine and chlorine are gases, bromine is a liquid, and iodine is a solid. All of the elements are colored, with the color becoming more intense moving down the group. Fluorine gas is pale yellow, and chlorine gas is a yellowish green. Liquid bromine and its vapors are brownish red. Solid iodine appears as shiny
topic: The role of radioactivity and short half-lives in limiting the study and practical chemistry of heavier halogens such as astatine and element 117.
question: Which of the following best explains why the chemistry of astatine and element 117 remains largely theoretical and unstudied, despite their placement in the halogen group?

choices.A: Their extreme radioactivity and very short half-lives prevent the isolation of sufficient quantities for compound formation and analysis.
choices.B: Their unique electron configurations make them chemically inert, limiting possible reactions with other elements.
choices.C: They are so reactive with water and oxygen that they cannot be handled outside of a vacuum.
choices.D: Their natural abundance is so high that experimental contamination makes pure samples impossible to obtain.

explanation: The main limitation to the study of astatine and element 117 arises from their intense radioactivity and extremely short half-lives, which cause them to decay into other elements before chemists can isolate or study their compounds in measurable amounts.

context: [DOC] [TLE] The Magic RoundaboutThe Magic Roundabout (known in the original French as Le Manège enchanté) was a French-British animated children's television programme created in France in 1963 by Serge Danot, with the help of Ivor Wood and Wood's French wife, Josiane. The series was originally broadcast from 1964 to 1971 on  ORTF (Office de Radiodiffusion Télévision Française). [PAR] Having originally rejected the series as "charming... but difficult to dub into English", the BBC later produced a version of the series using the original stop motion animation footage with new English-language scripts, written and narrated by Eric Thompson, which bore little relation to the original storylines. This version, broadcast in 441 five-minute-long episodes from 18 October 1965 to 25 January 1977, was a great success and attained cult status, and when in 1967 it was moved from the slot just before the evening news to an earlier children's viewing time, adult viewers complained to the BBC. [PAR] Characters [PAR] Although the characters are common to both versions, they were given different names and personalities depending on the language. [PAR] The main character is Dougal (Pollux in the original French-language version) who was a drop-eared variety of the Skye Terrier. [PAR] In the French version, Pollux is a British character who speaks somewhat broken French with an outrageous English accent as a result of Ivor Wood's role as co-creator. His sweet tooth, shown through his fondness for sugar lumps, was based on a French belief that one of the traits of the English is a liking for sweets. [PAR] Other characters include Zebedee (Zébulon), a jack-in-the-box; Brian (Ambroise), a snail; Ermintrude (Azalée), a cow, and Dylan (named after Bob Dylan[http://www.screenonline.org.uk/tv/id/591175/ Magic Roundabout, The (1965–77)] BFI Screenonline. Retrieved 23 August 2013.) (Flappy) a rabbit, who in the French version was Spanish. There are two notable human characters: Florence (Margote), a young girl; and Mr Rusty (le Père Pivoine), the elderly moustachioed operator of the roundabout (making him the second character to sport primarily a moustache, after Zebedee). Other less well known human characters, only seen on the roundabout itself during the credits, are Basil, Paul and Rosalie. There is also an adult character, old Mr McHenry (Jouvence Pio) the gardener who is seen only a couple of times. He is the only bearded character in the show and, despite his name and appearance, is Irish, not Scottish. [PAR] The show has a distinctive visual style. The set is a brightly coloured and stylised park containing the eponymous roundabout (a fairground carousel). The programmes were created by stop motion animation, which meant that Dougal was made without legs to make him easier to animate. Zebedee was created from a giant pea which was available in the animation studio and was re-painted. The look of these characters was the responsibility of British animator Ivor Wood, who was working at Danot's studio at the time (and who subsequently animated The Herbs, Paddington Bear and Postman Pat). [PAR] English-language version [PAR] The British (BBC) version was especially distinct from the French version in that the narration was entirely new, created by Eric Thompson from just the visuals, and not based on the script by Serge Danot. A former BBC employee, interviewed on BBC Radio in 2008, maintained that the original contract with the French owners did not include the scripts that accompanied the original animations (contrary to BBC assumptions). The BBC, instead of making a further payment to acquire the scripts, which would have required translation, decided to commission its own version – without access to the original French, and the English-language version therefore bears no resemblance to it. [PAR] The first British broadcasts were shown just before the 5.55 pm news every weekday on BBC 1, This was the first time an entertainment programme had been transmitted in this way in the UK. The original series, which was a serial, was made in black-and-white
topic: The broader cultural impact and reception of "The Magic Roundabout" in the UK, including its attainment of cult status and the reaction of adult viewers to scheduling changes.
question: What most plausibly explains the strong adult viewer reaction to the 1967 scheduling change of "The Magic Roundabout," and how does this relate to its subsequent cult status in the UK?

choices.A: Adults were invested in the show's subversive humor and unique narration, leading to cross-generational appeal that contributed to its cult status.
choices.B: The program’s earlier timeslot conflicted with adults' preferred evening news viewing, causing frustration unrelated to the show’s content.
choices.C: Adult complaints stemmed primarily from nostalgia for French animation and dissatisfaction with British adaptations.
choices.D: The BBC promoted the show specifically to adults, resulting in a predominantly adult fanbase and cult following.

explanation: The adult backlash to moving "The Magic Roundabout" earlier suggests its appeal extended beyond children, likely due to the distinctive, newly written narration and possible subversive or sophisticated humor. This broad, cross-generational appeal is a key factor in the program achieving cult status, rather than mere nostalgia, scheduling inconvenience, or targeted adult marketing.

context: [DOC] [TLE] South America | Map of South America - World MapSouth America Map, Map of South America [PAR] South America Industrial Centers [PAR] About South America [PAR] South America is the world's fourth largest continent on Earth, and the fifth most populous. With a history that spans over a thousand years, South America has been culturally influenced by Spanish, Portuguese, Asian, and African cultures. [PAR] Europeans explored South America beginning in the late fifteenth century, and the continent was named after Italian explorer Amerigo Vespucci who is believed to have recognized it as a separate continent. Located primarily in the southern hemisphere, with a few countries in the northern hemisphere, South America is comprised of twelve independent countries and three territories. [PAR] Geography [PAR] South America is bound by the Caribbean Sea in the north, the North Atlantic Ocean in the east and northeast and by the South Atlantic Ocean in the southeast. The South Pacific Ocean borders the continent in the west. In the northwest, the Isthmus of Panama joins South America with North America. South America is also home to a stunning variety of landscapes from desert to rainforest, and from plains to hills. [PAR] Historic Overview [PAR] South America has a long history, dating back to human migration across the Bering Land Bridge. By about 1200 BC hunters traveled from Asia to Alaska, crossing the Bering Strait and drifted gradually south. From 1400 to 1550, the indigenous people of the Inca Empire spread across South America to regions in modern-day Bolivia, Chile, Ecuador, Northern Argentina, and Peru. [PAR] In 1492, Christopher Columbus discovered the "New World", and the number of Spanish explorers increased between 1496 and 1526. In 1533, the Spanish Army led by Francisco Pizarro had captured much of Inca territory. In the period between 1535 and 1537, Argentina, Peru, and Bolivia were founded, and by the eighteenth century the Spanish colonies in South America started to make a serious bid for independence. While fighting wars against France on the European mainland, Spain began to lose control of its South American colonies, and by the end of the war in 1814, countries like Argentina and Venezuela gained their independence from Spain, and other nations followed suit. In the twentieth century, several South American countries, including Peru and Venezuela, had held elections for the first time after their independence. [PAR] Economy [PAR] The manufacturing industries, agriculture, and trade primarily support the economy of South America. The economies of many South American countries are based on export of goods, primarily the export of agricultural products. Brazil and Argentina lead in the export of goods to other nations. Some of the major agricultural products include sugarcane, corn, wheat, soybean, and coffee. South America's mineral resources also contribute substantially to the economy. Some major mineral resources found in South America are petroleum, gold, iron ore, silver, and copper. [PAR] South American countries have shown remarkable economic development in the past two decades. Countries like Brazil, Argentina, Columbia, Peru, Chile, and Uruguay have had maximum growth, even during the global recession of 2008 and 2009. South American countries have shown resilience as compared to other nations around the world. The major challenge that South America's economy faces is the high levels of inequality between the rich and the poor in many countries. The gap between the rich and the poor in South America is highest in the world. In response, many South American countries are trying to come together with the help of two trade blocs, the Mercosur, which includes countries like Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay, Venezuela, and Paraguay; and the Andean Community of Nations, which includes countries such as Ecuador, Bolivia, Peru, Columbia, Venezuela, and Chile. These trade blocs help the countries strengthen their economic ties and improve their economies. [PAR] Travel and Tourism [PAR] Tourism is another important industry in South America that not only enhances the GDP of each country, but also ensures greater job opportunities. The historical sites, architectural marvels, and the natural landscapes of the continent attract millions of tourists every year from all across the globe. [PAR] South America is a land of diversity. The Amazon Rainforest and Amazon
topic: The role of tourism in South America's economic development and its interaction with cultural and natural heritage.
question: Which of the following best characterizes the primary challenge South American countries face in leveraging tourism for economic development while preserving cultural and natural heritage?

choices.A: Ensuring that rapid tourism growth does not exacerbate economic inequality or lead to the degradation of heritage sites.
choices.B: Focusing solely on maximizing tourist numbers to increase GDP and job creation without regard for conservation efforts.
choices.C: Prioritizing agricultural exports over tourism to avoid pressure on cultural and natural landmarks.
choices.D: Restricting access to all historical and natural sites to preserve them, regardless of economic consequences.

explanation: The primary challenge lies in balancing the economic advantages of tourism—such as increased GDP and employment—with the risks of increased inequality, cultural commodification, and environmental degradation. Sustainable tourism development requires careful management to prevent negative impacts on heritage sites while still realizing economic gains.

context: [DOC] [TLE] FA Cup by numbers - TelegraphFA Cup by numbers - Telegraph [PAR] FA Cup by numbers [PAR] By Christopher Lyles [PAR] 12:01AM GMT 05 Jan 2008 [PAR] 0 The official attendance for two third-round replays that were played behind closed doors. The first was between Norwich City and Bradford City at Lincoln City's Sincil Bank ground in March 1915. Supporters were banned so as not to disrupt production at a nearby armaments factory. The second was between Leicester City and non-League Burton Albion at Coventry City's Highfield Road in 1985 when fans were banned because a missile had been thrown at the Burton goalkeeper in the first game. [PAR] Football fans' forum [PAR] 1 The number of clubs who have won the FA Cup at Wembley in the current millennium. Chelsea have done so twice, beating Aston Villa in 2000 and Manchester United last year. [PAR] 1 Occasion that the FA Cup has been won by a non-League club, in 1901 when Southern League Tottenham Hotspur beat First Division Sheffield United in a replay at Bolton. [PAR] 1 The number of non-English clubs who have won the FA Cup. Cardiff City became the first and only club to do so when they beat Arsenal 1-0 at Wembley in 1927. [PAR] 1 Scottish club who have played in an FA Cup final. Queen's Park were runners-up in 1884 and 1885. [PAR] 2 Clubs who have won the FA Cup in three successive years. Wanderers did so in 1876, 1877 and 1878 before Blackburn Rovers repeated the feat in 1884, 1885 and 1886. [PAR] 3 Successive years (between 1956 and 1958) in which Leeds United were drawn at home to Cardiff City in the third round. Cardiff won all three matches 2-1. [PAR] 3 Weeks between Wanderers winning the first FA Cup final in 1872 and being presented with the trophy at their annual dinner. [PAR] 4 Times in seven seasons (including the current one) that Aston Villa and Manchester United have been drawn together in the third round. [PAR] 4 FA Cup finals that have finished goalless. The last final without a goal was the 2005 contest between Arsenal and Manchester United, which Arsenal won 5-4 on penalties. The three previous goalless draws were in 1886, 1911 and 1912. [PAR] 4 Players who have represented three different clubs in an FA Cup final. They are Harold Halse (Manchester United, Aston Villa and Chelsea), Ernie Taylor (Newcastle United, Blackpool and Manchester United), John Barnes (Watford, Liverpool and Newcastle United) and Dennis Wise (Wimbledon, Chelsea and Millwall). [PAR] 5 FA Cup final winning teams that have been managed by Sir Alex Ferguson, more than any other manager. [PAR] 5 Occasions that Tottenham Hotspur have won the FA Cup when the year has ended in a "1". Spurs lifted the trophy in 1901, 1921, 1961, 1981 and 1991 (with their three other winning finals coming in 1962, 1967 and 1982). [PAR] 5 FA Cup final goals scored by Ian Rush, more than any other player. [PAR] 6 Games that it took for Alvechurch to beat Oxford City in the fourth qualifying round in 1971, the scores being 2-2, 1-1, 1-1, 0-0, 0-0 and (finally) 1-0. The FA Cup's longest ever tie lasted for an aggregate of 11 hours. [PAR] 6 The number worn by Manchester United's Kevin Moran when he became the first player to be sent off in a Cup final, against Everton in 1985. [PAR] 7 Years that Portsmouth were the FA Cup holders between 1939 and 1946, because of the Second World War. [PAR] 8 Times that the FA Cup has been won by a club playing outside the top flight of English football. The last time was in 1980 when West Ham United beat Arsenal thanks to Trevor Brooking's rare headed goal. [PAR] 9 Finals in which the Hon Arthur Kinnaird, who would later become president of the FA, played, a feat that remains unsurpassed. Kinnaird won three times with Wanderers, scoring in the 1873 and 1878 finals, and twice with Old Etonians. [PAR] 9 Goals that Ted MacDougall scored when
topic: The participation and performance of Scottish clubs in FA Cup finals, with emphasis on Queen's Park's appearances in the 1880s.
question: Which statement most accurately reflects the participation and outcome of Scottish clubs in FA Cup finals during the 1880s?

choices.A: Queen's Park became the only Scottish club to reach the FA Cup final, finishing as runners-up in both 1884 and 1885.
choices.B: Queen's Park won the FA Cup twice in the 1880s, making them the only Scottish winners of the competition.
choices.C: Multiple Scottish clubs reached the FA Cup finals in the 1880s, but none managed to secure a victory.
choices.D: No Scottish club has ever reached the FA Cup final, but several have made it to the semi-finals in the 1880s.

explanation: Only one Scottish club, Queen's Park, has played in an FA Cup final, finishing as runners-up in both 1884 and 1885; no Scottish club has ever won the competition or reached the final other than Queen's Park.

topic: The achievements of Hon Arthur Kinnaird in FA Cup finals and the evolution of individual influence in early football history.
question: In light of Hon Arthur Kinnaird’s record nine FA Cup final appearances—winning three times with Wanderers (scoring in two finals) and twice with Old Etonians—what does his achievement most compellingly illustrate about the nature of individual influence in early football history, particularly when contrasted with the structure of the modern game?

choices.A: The prevalence of amateurism allowed singular talents to dominate outcomes, underscoring the outsized impact of individuals in early football.
choices.B: The rules of early football limited individual contributions, making team tactics the primary determinant of success.
choices.C: Kinnaird’s achievements were typical of many players of the era, reflecting a highly egalitarian distribution of influence across teams.
choices.D: Early football finals were primarily determined by external factors such as weather and pitch conditions rather than player ability.

explanation: Kinnaird’s repeated appearances and decisive contributions in finals, especially across multiple clubs, exemplify how early football’s amateur and loosely organized structure enabled extraordinary individual influence, a dynamic less prevalent in the modern, professionalized era where collective tactics and systems overshadow singular talent.

SOPRANO [PAR] As many of us would know, the Soprano voice is the highest of the female voices, and many of us would be familiar with this voice type. [PAR] A typical Soprano vocal range would probably be from the A note below middle C (A3) to the F or G note 2 octaves above (F6 or G6), making it a range of 2 plus to 3 octaves. Of course, this is not to be taken as an exact measurement but more as a rough guideline for soprano voices, and proper breath support must be used when measuring vocal ranges during singing. [PAR] The Soprano Tessitura is also usually higher than the other female voice types, considering that the overall vocal range is the highest among the female voices. [PAR] A Soprano would also probably transition out of her chest voice around the E flat note above middle C (E4) and shift into her head voice around the F sharp note one octave above the middle C (F5). [PAR] The soprano voice usually has a bright tone, and she would usually have a strong head voice, but a relatively weaker middle voice. Sopranos are also able to sing more high notes and sustain at a high pitch better than a mezzo soprano can, and they are also most often the lead role for operas or shows. [PAR] 2. MEZZO SOPRANO [PAR] For most ladies out there, you would probably belong to this voice type as the Mezzo Soprano voice is the most common female voice type out of the 3 main types, and it lies between the higher Soprano voice and the lower Contralto voice. [PAR] The vocal range for the Mezzo Soprano voice would be likely between the G note below middle C (G3) to the C note more than 2 octaves above (C6), making it also a range of around slightly
topic: The relationship between vocal range, tessitura, and vocal timbre in assigning appropriate voice types for singers.
question: When assigning a singer to a specific voice type, why might a singer with a wide vocal range that reaches soprano notes still be more appropriately classified as a mezzo-soprano, and what would be the most decisive factor in such a case?

choices.A: Because her highest notes determine her type; range alone is sufficient for classification.
choices.B: Because her tessitura lies lower than a soprano's, making sustained singing in soprano repertoire less comfortable and less idiomatic for her voice.
choices.C: Because her vocal timbre is bright, which is always associated with sopranos regardless of range or tessitura.
choices.D: Because her register transition points are irrelevant if she can sing high notes; only range matters.

explanation: The most decisive factor in assigning voice type among singers with overlapping ranges is tessitura—the range in which the voice is most comfortable and resonant for sustained singing. Even if a singer can reach soprano notes, if her tessitura lies lower (as is typical for mezzo-sopranos), she will be better suited for mezzo-soprano roles, since these roles demand sustained singing within that optimal range, and her timbre may also be more characteristic of mezzos.

context: [DOC] [TLE] What are the Halogens in the Periodic Table? - QuoraWhat are the Halogens in the Periodic Table? - Quora [PAR] Quora [PAR] Daniel James Berger , PhD in organic chemistry [PAR] The elements in Group 17 of the periodic table  ( The Old fashioned name for Group 17 is Group VII ) are known collectively as The Halogens. [PAR] They are the elements Fluorine, ( atomic number 9 ),  Chlorine, ( atomic number 17 ), Bromine ( atomic number 35 ), Iodine ( atomic number 53 ), Astatine  ( atomic number 85 ), and a newly discovered element not yet given a name, that has an atomic number of 117, ( Discovered in 2010). [PAR] However both Astatine and Element No. 117 are too radioactive to be made in quantities that can be weighed. They are man made elements that have very short half lives;  so decay into other elements before one has the chance to make any of their compounds. So in most laboratories Halogen chemistry is essentially about the study of Fluorine, Chlorine, Bromine & Iodine. [PAR] The word Halogen was coined in 1842 by the Swedish Chemist Berzelius ( 1779 - 1848 ). It is a made up Swedish word which literally means "Salt producer" in Swedish. A name in keeping with the reactive nature of these elements. Lots of Halogen salts are known. Eg. Sodium chloride. Potassium fluoride. Sodium Bromide. [PAR]  These elements are all members of the same group, because all of their atoms have the same number of electrons in their outermost shell or orbit. Group 17 elements all have 7 electrons in their outermost orbit. [PAR] ​ [PAR] ​The Periodic Table highlighting Group 17. [PAR] Fluorine [PAR] As mentioned previously fluorine has an atomic number of 9. This means that an atom of fluorine will have in addition to 9 protons in the nucleus of its atom, it will have a total of 9 electrons orbiting its nucleus. An individual  proton always has a charge of +1 and an individual electron always has a charge of -1. [PAR] We have 9 protons in an atom of fluorine each having a charge of +1, plus 9 electrons in that same atom orbiting the nucleus of that atom. [PAR] ( +1 X 9 ) + (-1 X 9 ) = 0. [PAR]  So the atom is electrically neutral. [PAR] This is true for all neutral atoms of fluorine. [PAR] The 9 electrons are arranged in 2 shells or orbit.  2 of the 9 electrons orbit in the 1st shell or orbit. The remaining 7 electrons orbit in a larger shell. [PAR] The 7 electrons in the outermost orbit of all Halogens are the electrons that participate in chemical reactions. During chemical reactions the number of electrons in the outermost orbit can go up or down. Up to a max of 8, and down to 0 ( in theory ). Compare with  Na+1 or with Li+1 [PAR] ​ [PAR] Written Feb 7, 2016 [PAR] The halogens are the family of chemical elements that includes fluorine (atomic symbol F), chlorine (Cl), bromine (Br), iodine (I), and astatine (At). The halogens make up Group VIIA of the Periodic Table of the elements. Elemental halogens are diatomic molecules. However, due to their high reactivity, the halogens are never found in nature in native form. The family name means "salt-forming," from the Greek for salt, "hals", and for generating "genes". The salinity of the oceans on Earth is due in large part to such halogen salts (halides) as sodium chloride (NaCl) and potassium iodide (KI). [PAR] Halogens display physical and chemical properties typical of nonmetals. They have relatively low melting and boiling points that increase steadily down the group. Near room temperature, the halogens span all of the physical states: Fluorine and chlorine are gases, bromine is a liquid, and iodine is a solid. All of the elements are colored, with the color becoming more intense moving down the group. Fluorine gas is pale yellow, and chlorine gas is a yellowish green. Liquid bromine and its vapors are brownish red. Solid iodine appears as shiny
topic: The identification, atomic numbers, and historical naming conventions of halogens in the periodic table, including distinctions between Group 17 and Group VII designations.
question: Which of the following statements most accurately describes the evolution and distinction of group naming conventions for halogens in the periodic table, specifically regarding the historical use of Group VII, the modern Group 17 designation, and the implications for halogen identification?

choices.A: Group VII originally referred to all transition metals with seven valence electrons, but was redefined as Group 17 to clarify the inclusion of halogens only.
choices.B: The older Group VII nomenclature corresponds to the modern Group 17, but confusion arose from the parallel use of Group VIIA (halogens) and Group VIIB (transition metals), prompting IUPAC's adoption of Group 17 for halogens.
choices.C: Group 17 and Group VII have always exclusively denoted the halogens, with no overlap or ambiguity in the classification of other elements.
choices.D: The IUPAC's shift from Group VII to Group 17 was solely due to the discovery of new halogens, not because of systematic naming inconsistencies.

explanation: Option B correctly recognizes that the historical "Group VII" nomenclature led to confusion due to the A/B (American/British) system, where Group VIIA referred to halogens and Group VIIB to certain transition metals. The IUPAC standardized the group as Group 17 to eliminate this ambiguity and clarify the halogen group.

context: [DOC] [TLE] PLEASE SIR! | A TELEVISION HEAVEN REVIEWPLEASE SIR! | A TELEVISION HEAVEN REVIEW [PAR]   [PAR] PLEASE SIR! / THE FENN STREET GANG (1968) [PAR] Possibly inspired by the 1967 Sidney Potier movie, 'To Sir, With Love' -'Please Sir!' starred former Emergency Ward 10 actor John Alderton as newly qualified teacher Bernard Hedges (specialising in History and English), as he tried to tame the most unruly class at Fenn Street School; 5C. [PAR] On his first day at school Bernard crossed swords with caretaker Norman Potter (Deryck Guyler), a former Desert Rat with delusions of grandeur, although with some credibility as he was the right hand man of incompetent headmaster, Maurice Cromwell (Noel Howlett), who in turn was the subject of infatuation by formidable deputy head Doris Ewell (Joan Sanderson). This trio virtually ran the school much to the resignation of the rest of the disillusioned staff and the last thing they wanted to disturb the balance was a young schoolmaster fresh out of teachers training college and full of bright ideals about modern teaching. [PAR] In order to curb Bernard's naïve enthusiasm it was conspired between the trio to give him a class of 'no-hopers', namely 5C. In their last year at school the pupils of this class were an uneducable bunch of delinquents who were simply biding their time until the final bell sounded on the last day of term. This of course did not involve participating in any school activities such as lessons. However, through a series of (comical) events Bernard managed to win over not only the staff but also the class of pupils (who nicknamed him 'Privet' Hedges) that contained 'hard case' Patrick Duffy (Peter Cleall), the tough talking but wimpish Frankie (Hank) Abbott (David Barry), slow witted Dennis Dunstable (Peter Denyer), flirtatious Sharon (Penny Spencer in the first two season's, Carol Hawkins thereafter), and Maureen (Liz Gebhart), who had a crush on her teacher. Support on the teacher front came from Richard Davies who gave a first class performance as the down to earth no-nonsense Welsh science teacher, Mr Price, and the aging Eric Chitty as Mr Smith, a teacher that was clearly beyond retirement age at the series outset. In fact most of the actors who played the students were already in their twenties when Please Sir! began in 1968 and two years later (at the end of the longest last year in school history) the pupils were clearly showing their age. [PAR] The series made stars of several actors although oddly none of the students found lasting television fame. LWT Head of Light Entertainment, Frank Muir, cast Alderton as Bernard Hedges after he had spotted him as a teacher in the opening episode of Never A Cross Word. After leaving Fenn Street School the actor went on to several successful series such as Upstairs, Downstairs, it's spin-off series Thomas and Sarah, the LWT sitcom No-Honestly and a series of Wodehouse plays (Wodehouse Playhouse) for BBC (all of which Alderton co-starred alongside his wife, Pauline Collins), and the BBC sitcom My Wife Next Door with Hannah Gordon. Joan Sanderson won television immortality as Mrs Richards, the hotel guest with hearing problems in Fawlty Towers and after Please Sir! had finished she teamed up again with Deryck Guyler (who was originally cast as Fenn Street's headmaster) on a BBC radio show (also penned by the same writers), You're Only Young Once. [PAR] A 1971 feature movie was released in which Bernard meets and begins to date Penny Wheeler (Jill Kerman), and this was carried on in subsequent TV series of Please Sir! and its predecessor, The Fenn Street Gang (which in turn spawned Bowler), which briefly followed the fortunes of the pupils after they left school. [PAR] The series was the creation of former school chums and a new-to-television comedy writing team of John Esmonde and Bob Larbey, who went on to write Get Some In!; Ever Decreasing Circles; As Time Goes By and the enormously successful The Good Life. Actor David Barry has fond memories of working on
topic: The significance of casting choices, particularly the use of older actors for student roles, and its effects on realism and audience perception.
question: Which of the following best characterizes the impact of casting actors in their twenties as school students in "Please Sir!" on the show's realism and audience perception, especially as the series progressed?

choices.A: It enhanced the show's realism by allowing for more believable depictions of teenage life.
choices.B: It undermined the show's realism but was largely offset by the comedic tone, leading audiences to accept the age disparity as part of the show's style.
choices.C: It had minimal effect on the show's realism, as audiences prioritized narrative over casting authenticity.
choices.D: It caused audiences to reject the show entirely due to the glaring inauthenticity of the cast.

explanation: The casting of older actors as students became increasingly noticeable as the series went on, detracting from realism. However, the comedic nature of the show helped audiences accept the age gap as part of its stylized presentation, rather than leading to outright rejection or enhanced realism.

context: [DOC] [TLE] The Magic RoundaboutThe Magic Roundabout (known in the original French as Le Manège enchanté) was a French-British animated children's television programme created in France in 1963 by Serge Danot, with the help of Ivor Wood and Wood's French wife, Josiane. The series was originally broadcast from 1964 to 1971 on  ORTF (Office de Radiodiffusion Télévision Française). [PAR] Having originally rejected the series as "charming... but difficult to dub into English", the BBC later produced a version of the series using the original stop motion animation footage with new English-language scripts, written and narrated by Eric Thompson, which bore little relation to the original storylines. This version, broadcast in 441 five-minute-long episodes from 18 October 1965 to 25 January 1977, was a great success and attained cult status, and when in 1967 it was moved from the slot just before the evening news to an earlier children's viewing time, adult viewers complained to the BBC. [PAR] Characters [PAR] Although the characters are common to both versions, they were given different names and personalities depending on the language. [PAR] The main character is Dougal (Pollux in the original French-language version) who was a drop-eared variety of the Skye Terrier. [PAR] In the French version, Pollux is a British character who speaks somewhat broken French with an outrageous English accent as a result of Ivor Wood's role as co-creator. His sweet tooth, shown through his fondness for sugar lumps, was based on a French belief that one of the traits of the English is a liking for sweets. [PAR] Other characters include Zebedee (Zébulon), a jack-in-the-box; Brian (Ambroise), a snail; Ermintrude (Azalée), a cow, and Dylan (named after Bob Dylan[http://www.screenonline.org.uk/tv/id/591175/ Magic Roundabout, The (1965–77)] BFI Screenonline. Retrieved 23 August 2013.) (Flappy) a rabbit, who in the French version was Spanish. There are two notable human characters: Florence (Margote), a young girl; and Mr Rusty (le Père Pivoine), the elderly moustachioed operator of the roundabout (making him the second character to sport primarily a moustache, after Zebedee). Other less well known human characters, only seen on the roundabout itself during the credits, are Basil, Paul and Rosalie. There is also an adult character, old Mr McHenry (Jouvence Pio) the gardener who is seen only a couple of times. He is the only bearded character in the show and, despite his name and appearance, is Irish, not Scottish. [PAR] The show has a distinctive visual style. The set is a brightly coloured and stylised park containing the eponymous roundabout (a fairground carousel). The programmes were created by stop motion animation, which meant that Dougal was made without legs to make him easier to animate. Zebedee was created from a giant pea which was available in the animation studio and was re-painted. The look of these characters was the responsibility of British animator Ivor Wood, who was working at Danot's studio at the time (and who subsequently animated The Herbs, Paddington Bear and Postman Pat). [PAR] English-language version [PAR] The British (BBC) version was especially distinct from the French version in that the narration was entirely new, created by Eric Thompson from just the visuals, and not based on the script by Serge Danot. A former BBC employee, interviewed on BBC Radio in 2008, maintained that the original contract with the French owners did not include the scripts that accompanied the original animations (contrary to BBC assumptions). The BBC, instead of making a further payment to acquire the scripts, which would have required translation, decided to commission its own version – without access to the original French, and the English-language version therefore bears no resemblance to it. [PAR] The first British broadcasts were shown just before the 5.55 pm news every weekday on BBC 1, This was the first time an entertainment programme had been transmitted in this way in the UK. The original series, which was a serial, was made in black-and-white
topic: The significance of Dougal (Pollux) as the main character, including his breed, cultural traits, and the symbolic use of his fondness for sweets.
question: In "The Magic Roundabout," how does Dougal's characterization as a drop-eared Skye Terrier with a pronounced English accent and a strong fondness for sugar lumps serve as a complex symbol of Anglo-French cultural exchange, and what underlying purpose does his breed and sweet tooth fulfill within the show's cross-cultural context?

choices.A: His breed and sweet tooth visually and narratively reinforce British stereotypes for French audiences, serving as both affectionate satire and a marker of difference, while his design also facilitates animation constraints.
choices.B: His breed was chosen purely for animation convenience, and his fondness for sugar lumps simply adds comedic value, with no deeper cultural significance.
choices.C: Dougal's characterization primarily reflects French rural animal archetypes, intended to resonate only with local viewers and not to signify cross-cultural themes.
choices.D: The choice of a Skye Terrier and his sweet tooth were imposed by BBC producers to appeal to British children, disregarding any French cultural interpretations.

explanation: Option A synthesizes Dougal's breed and personality as intentionally crafted symbols reflecting and playfully exaggerating Britishness for a French audience, embodying cultural stereotypes, while also considering animation practicality; the other options either ignore the cross-cultural symbolism, misattribute intent, or overlook the layered purposes behind these choices.

context: [DOC] [TLE] South America | Map of South America - World MapSouth America Map, Map of South America [PAR] South America Industrial Centers [PAR] About South America [PAR] South America is the world's fourth largest continent on Earth, and the fifth most populous. With a history that spans over a thousand years, South America has been culturally influenced by Spanish, Portuguese, Asian, and African cultures. [PAR] Europeans explored South America beginning in the late fifteenth century, and the continent was named after Italian explorer Amerigo Vespucci who is believed to have recognized it as a separate continent. Located primarily in the southern hemisphere, with a few countries in the northern hemisphere, South America is comprised of twelve independent countries and three territories. [PAR] Geography [PAR] South America is bound by the Caribbean Sea in the north, the North Atlantic Ocean in the east and northeast and by the South Atlantic Ocean in the southeast. The South Pacific Ocean borders the continent in the west. In the northwest, the Isthmus of Panama joins South America with North America. South America is also home to a stunning variety of landscapes from desert to rainforest, and from plains to hills. [PAR] Historic Overview [PAR] South America has a long history, dating back to human migration across the Bering Land Bridge. By about 1200 BC hunters traveled from Asia to Alaska, crossing the Bering Strait and drifted gradually south. From 1400 to 1550, the indigenous people of the Inca Empire spread across South America to regions in modern-day Bolivia, Chile, Ecuador, Northern Argentina, and Peru. [PAR] In 1492, Christopher Columbus discovered the "New World", and the number of Spanish explorers increased between 1496 and 1526. In 1533, the Spanish Army led by Francisco Pizarro had captured much of Inca territory. In the period between 1535 and 1537, Argentina, Peru, and Bolivia were founded, and by the eighteenth century the Spanish colonies in South America started to make a serious bid for independence. While fighting wars against France on the European mainland, Spain began to lose control of its South American colonies, and by the end of the war in 1814, countries like Argentina and Venezuela gained their independence from Spain, and other nations followed suit. In the twentieth century, several South American countries, including Peru and Venezuela, had held elections for the first time after their independence. [PAR] Economy [PAR] The manufacturing industries, agriculture, and trade primarily support the economy of South America. The economies of many South American countries are based on export of goods, primarily the export of agricultural products. Brazil and Argentina lead in the export of goods to other nations. Some of the major agricultural products include sugarcane, corn, wheat, soybean, and coffee. South America's mineral resources also contribute substantially to the economy. Some major mineral resources found in South America are petroleum, gold, iron ore, silver, and copper. [PAR] South American countries have shown remarkable economic development in the past two decades. Countries like Brazil, Argentina, Columbia, Peru, Chile, and Uruguay have had maximum growth, even during the global recession of 2008 and 2009. South American countries have shown resilience as compared to other nations around the world. The major challenge that South America's economy faces is the high levels of inequality between the rich and the poor in many countries. The gap between the rich and the poor in South America is highest in the world. In response, many South American countries are trying to come together with the help of two trade blocs, the Mercosur, which includes countries like Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay, Venezuela, and Paraguay; and the Andean Community of Nations, which includes countries such as Ecuador, Bolivia, Peru, Columbia, Venezuela, and Chile. These trade blocs help the countries strengthen their economic ties and improve their economies. [PAR] Travel and Tourism [PAR] Tourism is another important industry in South America that not only enhances the GDP of each country, but also ensures greater job opportunities. The historical sites, architectural marvels, and the natural landscapes of the continent attract millions of tourists every year from all across the globe. [PAR] South America is a land of diversity. The Amazon Rainforest and Amazon
topic: The factors contributing to South America's resilience and economic growth during global recessions, with reference to specific countries.
question: Which combination of factors most plausibly explains the resilience and continued economic growth of countries such as Brazil, Argentina, Chile, and Peru during global recessions, as opposed to other world regions?

choices.A: Large-scale tourism industries and advanced technological sectors
choices.B: Agricultural and mineral export strength, regional trade bloc cooperation, and diversified manufacturing bases
choices.C: Reliance on domestic consumption and limited engagement in international trade
choices.D: Predominant focus on service industries and minimal natural resource extraction

explanation: The countries named experienced resilience and growth during global recessions primarily due to their strong agricultural and mineral export sectors, collaborative efforts through trade blocs like Mercosur and the Andean Community, and diversified manufacturing industries. This multifaceted economic structure provided buffers against global downturns. Tourism and services are important but not the primary drivers, while reliance on domestic consumption or minimal resource extraction does not align with the described economic model.
